{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3156848,"name":"James Goebel","username":"JGOEBEL7777","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e56c9b/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-04T02:06:10.739Z","cooked":"

We connected a redline 775 on a 1:48 transmission and the motor smoke after
clamping an object for 1 minute. We also had a similar problem with the same
motor and transmission on our arm lift. These were new motors and transmissions.
Is anyone experiencing problems like this with redline 775 and a spark max?
Last year we used the 775 for the two-stage Andymark climber and they worked
without a problem with 2 rev victor spx. I know they have a limit to the stall time but
the time seemed too short to be usable. Thanks.

What voltage are you stalling them at? For your arm, do you have any sort of counter-balance or braking mechanism to assist with holding position?

775s are not intended to stall for prolonged periods (as no motor really is), and particularly at higher voltages it will cause the motor to fail rapidly. Select gear ratios to limit the load on these motors, and be thoughtful when programming to avoid unnecessarily large inputs for prolonged periods of time.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2023-03-04T02:41:58.761Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":88.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":428833,"topic_slug":"2023-cone-lift-bot-motor-redline-775-motor-smokes-after-8-tests-on-grabber","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/2023-cone-lift-bot-motor-redline-775-motor-smokes-after-8-tests-on-grabber/428833/2","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3156880,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-04T03:14:27.904Z","cooked":"

If you download the locked rotor data (csv file), you will see that at 1 second, it draws about 10A per volt (100 milliohm) The more you draw, the faster it rises. It looks like setting a 40A or smaller current limit will allow you to hold a game piece for a full match.

While the locked rotor test doesnt show it, if you can find a way to run these at high speed low current (e.g. disengaging the gears), the fan in the motor will quickly cool it. Your motor controllers wonâ€™t be so lucky, of course.

Curiously, team 5437 released the blue smoke of a 775 pro on an intake in match 45 at Arkansas right in front of me today. 5437 is located midfield, just a bit on the red and scoring table sides of the actual center of the field, facing towards the scoring table. In this case, it was an intake stalled in being held open rather than closed, tomayto tomahto. You can make out several puffs of smoke in the video that dissipated quickly as far as being visible, but were noticed by noses for several minutes. The first puff of smoke is about 1:10; this starts about 3 seconds before:
Qualification 45 - 2023 Arkansas Regional - YouTube.
I passed on the same advice to a couple of Rocky Balboabots members when one of my spare moments intersected with theirs.

On the lift arm, I changed to a heavy CIM motor with 48:1 and a Large spring to
take some weight off the arm and it seems to work. I am considering
ordering the 100:1 transmission if that would help but they are out of stock.
The grabber I used the motor to close the grabber with springs on
the other side to open the grabber for another use.
I am going to reduce the current setting on the spark max to 40 amp
as you said. Will the spark max then be in danger of burning out?
I am considering reversing the motor position so it
only works to open for the cube/cone grab and a spring closes it.
I think this may be hard to accomplish due to the differences between
the cone and the cube. Thatâ€™s why they call it prototyping.
Thankâ€™s all for the suggestions and help and video.
